item.title: Static websites are still cool
item.description:
Nowadays most of the websites are built using a Content Management System or CMS such as WordPress, Drupal or Joomla. They allow the user to manage all their content through nice administrator control screens, and PHP, ASP.NET, or whatever server side technology the CMS is built on, will magically and dynamically create the website pages every single time a visitor hits the page.

Building a website using a CMS is one of the many ways the Internet has become so powerful, since the old days when all websites were just a link or two and a flash banner. However it’s not the only way, building websites exclusively on .html static files is still one of the most efficient methods of creating fast and secure websites.

What is a static .html site anyway?

A static site is the opposite of a dynamic one. This doesn’t mean that nothing on a static site moves, it means that the site is made in such a way that its .html content has already been pre-generated and is just laying out on the web server, as opposed to all the content being stored in a database waiting to be dynamically mashed together when a request comes by a server side technology like PHP.

When we first heard about Jekyll, Rake, and a few other technologies to pre-generate a static site in seconds, we really wondered why would anyone want a static .html site with the options we have today in CMS products?

Why static .html sites?

  • Performance. Seconds can mean the difference between someone getting frustrated and leaving your website versus them staying and reading, buying, or clicking your ad. With static .html, your site is ready and rearing to go because there is no database to query from or server side scripting to parse. Static websites are fast, superfast, since they are pure HTML.
  • No MySQL calls for WordPress or Joomla. No mashing together of content and templates, all that’s been done already. HTML is what browsers read and they don’t know PHP or ASP.NET, all they know is HTML markup, and it’s already there waiting for them.
  • Security is another thing static sites solve. When building websites we constantly need to watch for SQL injection or other trickeries from the bad guys. With static sites, the majority of the security issues go away since the site doesn’t have any database to inject SQL to. It’s just a set of read-only files sitting out on a file server. Where WordPress or other CMS products have access (potentially write) to the database, they are inherently more hacker-prone than static files.
  • HTML is portable. With static websites there is no more PHP, ASP.NET or Java requirements for the web server. HTML is the most portable website technology of all time, because at the end of the day, it’s THE web technology, and can be moved from Apache to IIS to Nginx to whatever host environment we need and it’s guaranteed it’ll work just as great as before we made the move.

When to go with static websites?

A good analogy for comparing static websites versus dynamic ones is whether the website could be printed out and still function properly. If the website will show information that is designed to be read, then we could print each page out and with the exception of any hyperlinks we may have, it would still work. For this the best option is to go with static websites due the advantages mentioned above.

However if the website needs to be interactive and capable of being used by people who will use it not just for reading, the best option is to go with a dynamic website, built on a CMS or custom web development.

item.title: How we made softelos.com
item.description:
Our website is no different from other web projects we develop for our customers. We follow the same values and apply the same principles when creating software for us.

This article describes how we did this with www.softelos.com.

.. discuss your needs

This is the first and most important stage of any web design or web development project we work on. During this stage we meet with our customers to learn about their business and needs, and to discuss their requirements for the web design or development.

After a call to briefly introduce each other and to get a quick glimpse of what the customer needs, we usually meet in person for this stage. Sometimes when the project is very complex, we might need more than one session in order to gather all the information we need to develop the project.

In the case of Softelos, we are our own customers, and we needed a web site with the following requirements:

  1. The content has to summarize who we are, what we do and our values.
  2. The design has to be attractive but light.
  3. The design has to support mobile devices.
  4. The design has to load fast.
  5. The content doesn’t flood the visitor with unnecessary information and graphics.
  6. A form that allows visitors to send inquiries.
  7. A blog where news, events and other interesting content can be published periodically to all visitors.

.. think of an unique idea

In this stage we review all the requirements gathered during our meetings with our customer and brainstorm amazing ways of implementing them in a unique way. During this stage we also evaluate different possible technologies and pick the one that fits the project needs in the most efficient way.

For www.softelos.com we decided to go very simple and implement the website in pure HTML, with no databases or server side scripting. This makes our website simple, light and very secure.

Many web design agencies use content management systems (CMS) for everything they do, no matter the size or requirements of the website or web development they are working on. Softelos takes a different approach, we are experts in many different web design and software development technologies, and we apply them when they make sense.

See why we don’t use Wordpress to learn more about our philosophy.

.. design the concept

This is when the fun starts!

Once we have defined the customer’s requirements, selected a couple of design ideas and chosen the technology to use, we are able to turn all them into reality.

First we start creating a wire frame structure of the website or web development, with no graphics and real content. This helps us to show to our customer how the project is taking shape and also allows us to get feedback if something needs change.

Once the customer is happy with the wire frame structure and all his requests and changes have been applied, we proceed to apply the “skin” to the wire frame, which includes colors, pictures and real content.

The initial visual concept is ready!

.. you comment and we amend

During this stage we meet with our customer to discuss the initial visual concept and refine based on their feedback. Adding extra touches here and there just enhances the design for perfection.

.. website development

Once all the designs have been completed, it’s time to get the programming started. At this stage all features and functionality would have been clarified. Our developers use this specification to build the site.

Although www.softelos.com doesn’t require any server side scripting (development), still needs JavaScript code that makes possible some cool features such as the top header expanding and collapsing when scrolling the browser. This is an example of what is implemented in this stage.

.. show it to the world

After intense testing and another round of feedback, we prepare to publish the master piece to the world. This is usually done by announcing the site as an email newsletter that we design and send to your customers.

In our case since our site is pure HTML, CSS and JavaScript, we don’t need an expensive hosting provider. For Softelos we are using GitHub, a source version control site that offers free hosting for web sites with no server side scripting or database support.

item.title: We have launched!
item.description:
After many years working as professionals for different companies, we finally decided to make our dream come true and launch Softelos, a small web design and development agency based in our lovely city of Lynchburg, right in the heart of the state of Virginia.

We come from different educational and professional backgrounds, but we share the same passion for web design, web development and software technologies in general. We used to live in Spain, where we worked for different industrial and technical companies. In 2008 we had the opportunity to travel to the US and visit Lynchburg for work related issues.

I remember that once at the Washington Dulles Airport customs, the emigration officer didn’t even know where the city was, he even asked me “what I lost there that I needed to go”. What we couldn’t imagine at that moment is that we were going to fall in love with this city, its people, its way of life, and with the state of Virginia in general.

Five years later we moved for good and established this city as the place where to raise a family!
